title: 111_s2770
content: The "Veterans Business Center Act of 2009" may be cited as the official title of this Act. It establishes the Veterans Business Center Program. Section 32 of the Small Business Act is amended to establish a Veterans Business Center Program to provide entrepreneurial training and counseling to veterans. A Director will be appointed to oversee the program and report to the Associate Administrator for Veterans Business Development. The Director will establish criteria for designating veterans business centers. The Director will establish a process to designate entities as veterans business centers and publicly announce the designation and grant awards. Initial grants of $200,000 will be provided to each veterans business center annually for up to 5 years, with additional growth funding grants available after the initial period. The Director can grant $150,000 annually for up to 3 years to veterans business centers for growth funding. After 3 years, centers must meet performance benchmarks for continued funding. Centers must use funds for veteran entrepreneurial development, counseling, and government procurement assistance. The Director can grant $150,000 annually for up to 3 years to veterans business centers for growth funding. Centers must provide a 50% non-Federal match and may request a waiver based on hardship. Priority is given to applications for designations and grants in targeted areas. The Director can grant funding for veterans business centers in underserved areas with high veteran populations, particularly those from Operation Iraqi Freedom or Operation Enduring Freedom. Additionally, an annual training program is developed for center staff to enhance their knowledge and skills. The Director develops a training program for veterans business centers in consultation with various organizations. Veterans Business Outreach Centers and centers funded by the National Veterans Business Development Corporation are eligible for grants under this program. The Director develops a training program for veterans business centers in consultation with various organizations. Veterans Business Outreach Centers and centers funded by the National Veterans Business Development Corporation shall be eligible for grants under this subsection. The Director submits an annual report on veterans in rural areas' access to veterans business centers, giving priority to establishing centers in rural areas if access is inadequate. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out this subsection. The Director of the Veterans Business Center program is authorized to make grants to assist veteran-owned small businesses in securing capital and repairing credit. Grants may also be used for providing informational seminars on securing loans for veteran-owned small businesses. The Veterans Business Center program offers grants to help veteran-owned small businesses secure loans, improve financial presentations, access financing sources, and provide counseling to reserve component members of the armed forces preparing their businesses. The Veterans Business Center program offers grants to assist veteran-owned small businesses in preparing for deployment during contingency operations and to help unemployed veterans become entrepreneurs. The Director may award a center up to $75,000 in grants, with $1,500,000 authorized for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. Additionally, a procurement assistance grant program will be established by the Director. The Director can provide grants to veterans business centers to assist veteran-owned small businesses in identifying suitable contracts, preparing them for subcontractor and prime contractor roles, and offering training and advisement, especially in construction trades. The Director can provide grants to veterans business centers for technical assistance in Federal procurement processes, compliance with regulations, and bonding requirements. The maximum grant award is $75,000, with an authorization of $1,500,000 for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. Additionally, a grant program for service-disabled veteran-owned small businesses will be established by the Director. The Director can award grants up to $75,000 to veterans business centers for outreach programs, training service-disabled veterans in various business aspects, and assisting them in securing business opportunities. The Director can award grants of more than $75,000 to veterans business centers for various programs. Authorization of appropriations is set at $1,500,000 for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. Additionally, the Veterans Entrepreneurial Development Summit is authorized for networking, outreach, education, and training opportunities for veteran-owned businesses and organizations. The Director can award grants for education and training to improve outreach to veterans in high unemployment areas. $450,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. Surviving spouses are included in the definition of 'veteran' and 'veteran-owned small business'. The term 'veteran' now includes members of the reserve components of the Armed Forces as specified in section 10101 of title 10, United States Code. This also extends to 'veteran-owned small businesses' owned by reserve component members. The Small Business Act is amended to require biannual reporting on interagency task force appointments and activities. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the impact of the Act on small businesses owned by veterans, providing recommendations for better implementation.
